frames.core

Class Graph

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.core.Graph
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Scene

    public class Graph
extends java.lang.Object
    A 2D or 3D scene graph providing eye, input and timing handling to a raster or ray-tracing renderer.

    1. Types and dimensions

    A graph uses a ball to set the 2d or 3d viewing space (instead of the more traditional methods to set a 3d viewing frustum). See setCenter(Vector) and setRadius(float), and also setZClippingCoefficient(float) and setZNearCoefficient(float) for a 3d graph. See also setBoundingBox(Vector, Vector).

    The way the projection() matrix is computed (see computeProjection()), defines the type of the graph as: Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE, Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC for 3d graphs and Graph.Type.TWO_D for a 2d graph. To set a Graph.Type.CUSTOM override computeCustomProjection().

    2. Scene graph handling

    A graph forms a tree of (attached) Frames which may be traverse(), calling Frame.visit() on each visited frame (refer to the Frame documentation). Note that traverse() should be called within your main-event loop.

    The frame collection belonging to the graph may be retrieved with frames(). The graph provides other useful routines to handle the hierarchy, such as pruneBranch(Frame), appendBranch(List), isReachable(Frame), branch(Frame), and clear().

    2.1. Eye handling

    Any Frame (belonging or not to the graph hierarchy) may be set as the eye() (see setEye(Frame)). Several frame wrapper functions to handle the eye, such as lookAt(Vector), at(), setViewDirection(Vector), setUpVector(Vector), upVector(), fitFieldOfView(), fieldOfView(), setHorizontalFieldOfView(float), fitBall() screenLocation(Vector, Frame) and location(Vector, Frame), are provided for convenience.

    3. Interactivity

    Several methods taking a Frame parameter provide interactivity to frames, such as translate(float, float, float, Frame), rotate(float, float, float, Frame) and scale(float, Frame).

    Some interactivity methods are only available for the eye() and hence they don't take a frame parameter, such as lookAround(float, float) or rotateCAD(float, float).

    Call control(Frame, Object...) to send arbitrary gesture data to the frame. Note that Frame.interact(Object...) should be overridden to implement the frame custom behavior.

    To check if a given frame would be picked with a ray casted at a given screen position use tracks(float, float, Frame). Refer to Frame.precision() (and Frame.setPrecision(Frame.Precision)) for the different frame picking policies.

    4. Human Interface Devices

    Setting up a Human Interface Device (hid) is a two step process: 1. Define an hid tracked-frame instance, using an arbitrary name for it (see setTrackedFrame(String, Frame)); and, 2. Call any interactivity method that take an hid param (such as translate(String, float, float, float), rotate(String, float, float, float) or scale(String, float)) following the name convention you defined in 1. Observations:
    1. An hid tracked-frame (see trackedFrame(String)) defines in turn an hid default-frame (see defaultFrame(String)) which simply returns the tracked-frame or the eye() when the hid tracked-frame is null.
    2. The hid interactivity methods are implemented in terms of the ones defined previously by simply passing the hid defaultFrame(String) to them (e.g., scale(String, float) calls scale(float, Frame) passing the hid default-frame).
    3. The default hid is defined with a null String parameter (e.g., scale(float delta) simply calls scale(null, delta)).
    4. To update an hid tracked-frame using ray-casting call track(String, Point, Frame[]) (detached or attached frames), track(String, Point) (only attached frames) or cast(String, Point) (only for attached frames too). While track(String, Point, Frame[]) and track(String, Point) update the hid tracked-frame synchronously (i.e., they return the hid tracked-frame immediately), cast(String, Point) updates it asynchronously (i.e., it optimally updates the hid tracked-frame during the next call to the traverse() algorithm).

    5. Timing handling

    The graph performs timing handling through a timingHandler(). Several TimingHandler wrapper functions, such as registerTask(TimingTask) and registerAnimator(Animator), are provided for convenience.

    A default interpolator() may perform several eye() interpolations such as fitBallInterpolation(), zoomOnRegionInterpolation(Rectangle), interpolateTo(Frame) and interpolateTo(Frame, float). Refer to the Interpolator documentation for details.

    6. Visibility and culling techniques

    Geometry may be culled against the viewing volume by calling isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float) or boxVisibility(Vector, Vector). Make sure to call enableBoundaryEquations() first, since update of the viewing volume boundary equations are disabled by default (see enableBoundaryEquations() and areBoundaryEquationsEnabled()).

    7. Matrix handling

    The graph performs matrix handling through a matrixHandler(). To set shader matrices use projection(), modelView() (which wrap MatrixHandler functions with the same signatures) and (possibly) Matrix.multiply(projection(), modelView()).

    To apply the transformation defined by a frame call applyTransformation(Frame) (see also applyWorldTransformation(Frame)) between pushModelView() and popModelView() (which wrap MatrixHandler functions with the same signatures). Note that the frame transformations are applied automatically by the traverse() algorithm (in this case you don't need to call them).

    To define your geometry on the screen coordinate system (such as when drawing 2d controls on top of a 3d graph) issue your drawing code between beginHUD() and endHUD(). These methods are MatrixHandler wrapper functions with the same signatures provided for convenience.

    To bind a graph to a third party renderer override MatrixHandler and set it with setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler) (refer to the MatrixHandler documentation for details).

    See Also:
    TimingHandler, applyTransformation(Frame), MatrixHandler

        Graph(Type, int, int)

      • Graph

        public Graph(Graph.Type type,
             int width,
             int height)
        Default constructor defines a right-handed graph with the specified width and height screen window dimensions. The graph center() and anchor() are set to (0,0,0) and its radius() to 100.

        The constructor sets a Frame instance as the graph eye() and then calls fitBall(), so that the entire scene fits the screen dimensions.

        The constructor also instantiates the graph matrixHandler() and timingHandler().

        Third party graphs should additionally:

        1. (Optionally) Define a custom matrixHandler(). Only if the target platform (such as Processing) provides its own matrix handling.
        See Also:
        timingHandler(), setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler), setRightHanded(), setEye(Frame)

    • Method Detail

        public Frame randomFrame()
        Same as return Frame.random(this). Creates a random frame attached to this graph.

      • setWidth

        public void setWidth(int width)
        Sets eye width() and height() (expressed in pixels).

        Non-positive dimension are silently replaced by a 1 pixel value to ensure boundary coherence.

      • setHeight

        public void setHeight(int height)

      • type

        public Graph.Type type()
        Returns the graph type. Set by setType(Type).
        See Also:
        setType(Type)

      • setType

        public void setType(Graph.Type type)
        Defines the graph type().

        A Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE uses a classical projection mainly defined by its fieldOfView(). With a Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC, the fieldOfView() is meaningless and the width and height of the graph frustum are inferred from the distance to the anchor() using boundaryWidthHeight(). Both types use zNear() and zFar() (to define their clipping planes) and aspectRatio() (for frustum shape).

        A Graph.Type.TWO_D behaves like Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC, but instantiated graph frames will be constrained so that they will remain at the x-y plane. See Constraint.

        To set a Graph.Type.CUSTOM override computeCustomProjection().

      • fieldOfView

        public float fieldOfView()
        Returns the vertical field of view of the eye() (in radians) computed as 2 * (float) Math.atan(eye().magnitude()).

        Value is set using setFieldOfView(float). Default value is pi/3 radians. This value is meaningless if the graph type() is Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC.

        The field of view corresponds the one used in gluPerspective. It sets the Y (vertical) aperture of the eye. The X (horizontal) angle is inferred from the window aspect ratio (see aspectRatio() and horizontalFieldOfView()).

        See Also:
        setFieldOfView(float), eye()

      • setFieldOfView

        public void setFieldOfView(float fov)
        Same as eye().setMagnitude((float) Math.tan(fov / 2)).

        Sets the field-of-view of the current eye().

        See Also:
        Frame.setMagnitude(float)

      • horizontalFieldOfView

        public float horizontalFieldOfView()
        Returns the horizontal field of view of the eye() (in radians).

        Value is set using setHorizontalFieldOfView(float) or setFieldOfView(float). These values are always linked by: horizontalFieldOfView() = 2 * atan ( tan(fieldOfView()/2) * aspectRatio() ).

      • fitFieldOfView

        public void fitFieldOfView()
        Changes the eye() fieldOfView() so that the entire scene (defined by center() and radius()) is visible.

        The eye position and orientation are not modified and you first have to orientate the eye in order to actually see the scene (see lookAt(Vector), fitBall() or fitBall(Vector, float)). Attention: The fieldOfView() is clamped to PI/2. This happens when the eye is at a distance lower than sqrt(2) * radius() from the center().

        See Also:
        setFieldOfView(float)

      • setHorizontalFieldOfView

        public void setHorizontalFieldOfView(float hfov)
        Sets the horizontalFieldOfView() of the eye() (in radians).

        horizontalFieldOfView() and fieldOfView() are linked by the aspectRatio(). This method actually calls: setFieldOfView(( 2 * atan (tan(hfov / 2) / aspectRatio()) )) so that a call to horizontalFieldOfView() returns the expected value.

      • zNear

        public float zNear()
        Returns the near clipping plane distance used by computeProjection() matrix in world units.

        The clipping planes' positions depend on the radius() and center() rather than being fixed small-enough and large-enough values. A good approximation will hence result in an optimal precision of the z-buffer.

        The near clipping plane is positioned at a distance equal to zClippingCoefficient() * radius() in front of the center(): Vector.scalarProjection( Vector.subtract(eye().position(), center()), eye().zAxis()) - zClippingCoefficient() * radius()

        In order to prevent negative or too small zNear() values (which would degrade the z precision), zNearCoefficient() is used when the eye is inside the radius() sphere:

        zMin = zNearCoefficient() * zClippingCoefficient() * radius();
        zNear = zMin;
        With an ORTHOGRAPHIC and TWO_D types, the value is simply clamped to 0

        See also the zFar(), zClippingCoefficient() and zNearCoefficient() documentations.

        If you need a completely different zNear computation, overload the zNear() and zFar() methods. Attention: The value is always positive, although the clipping plane is positioned at a negative z value in the eye coordinate system.

        See Also:
        zFar()

      • zFar

        public float zFar()
        Returns the far clipping plane distance used by the computeProjection() matrix in world units.

        The far clipping plane is positioned at a distance equal to zClippingCoefficient() * radius() behind the center():

        zFar = Vector.scalarProjection(Vector.subtract(eye().position(), center()), eye().zAxis()) + zClippingCoefficient() * radius()

        See Also:
        zNear()

      • zNearCoefficient

        public float zNearCoefficient()
        Returns the coefficient used to set zNear() when the eye() is inside the sphere defined by center() and zClippingCoefficient() * radius().

        In that case, the zNear() value is set to zNearCoefficient() * zClippingCoefficient() * radius(). See the zNear() documentation for details.

        Default value is 0.005, which is appropriate for most applications. In case you need a high dynamic ZBuffer precision, you can increase this value (~0.1). A lower value will prevent clipping of very close objects at the expense of a worst Z precision.

        Only meaningful when the graph type is PERSPECTIVE.

      • setZNearCoefficient

        public void setZNearCoefficient(float coef)
        Sets the zNearCoefficient() value.

      • zClippingCoefficient

        public float zClippingCoefficient()
        Returns the coefficient used to position the near and far clipping planes.

        The near (resp. far) clipping plane is positioned at a distance equal to zClippingCoefficient() * radius() in front of (resp. behind) the center(). This guarantees an optimal use of the z-buffer range and minimizes aliasing. See the zNear() and zFar() documentations.

        Default value is square root of 3 (so that a cube of edge size 2*radius() is not clipped).

        See Also:
        zNearCoefficient()

      • setZClippingCoefficient

        public void setZClippingCoefficient(float coef)
        Sets the zClippingCoefficient() value.

      • boundaryWidthHeight

        public float[] boundaryWidthHeight()
        Returns the halfWidth and halfHeight of the eye boundary. While first element holds halfWidth, the second one holds halfHeight. Values are computed as: _rescalingFactor() * (eye().magnitude() * width() / 2) and _rescalingFactor() * (eye().magnitude() * height() / 2), respectively.

        These values are valid for 2d and orthographic graphs (but not perspective) and they are expressed in virtual world units.

        In the case of orthographs graphs these values are proportional to the eye (z projected) distance to the anchor(). When zooming on the object, the eye is translated forward and its boundary is narrowed, making the object appear bigger on screen, as intuitively expected.

        Overload this method to change this behavior if desired.

        See Also:
        _rescalingFactor()

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Same as for(Frame frame : _leadingFrames()) pruneBranch(frame).
        See Also:
        pruneBranch(Frame)

      • pruneBranch

        public java.util.List<Frame> pruneBranch(Frame frame)
        Make all the frames in the frame branch eligible for garbage collection.

        A call to isReachable(Frame) on all frame descendants (including frame) will return false, after issuing this method. It also means that all frames in the frame branch will become unreachable by the traverse() algorithm.

        To make all the frames in the branch reachable again, first cache the frames belonging to the branch (i.e., branch=pruneBranch(frame)) and then call appendBranch(List) on the cached branch. Note that calling Frame.setReference(Frame) on a frame belonging to the pruned branch will become reachable again by the traversal algorithm.

        When collected, pruned frames behave like Frame, otherwise they are eligible for garbage collection.

        See Also:
        clear(), appendBranch(List), isReachable(Frame)

      • appendBranch

        public void appendBranch(java.util.List<Frame> branch)
        Appends the branch which typically should come from the one pruned (and cached) with pruneBranch(Frame).

        pruneBranch(Frame)

      • isReachable

        public boolean isReachable(Frame frame)
        Returns true if the frame is reachable by the traverse() algorithm and false otherwise.

        Frames are made unreachable with pruneBranch(Frame) and reachable again with Frame.setReference(Frame).

        See Also:
        traverse(), frames()

      • frames

        public java.util.List<Frame> frames()
        Returns a list of all the frames that are reachable by the traverse() algorithm.

        The method traverse the hierarchy to collect. Frame collections should thus be kept at user space for efficiency.

        See Also:
        isReachable(Frame), isEye(Frame)

      • branch

        public java.util.List<Frame> branch(Frame frame)
        Collects frame and all its descendant frames. Note that for a frame to be collected it must be reachable.
        See Also:
        isReachable(Frame)

      • path

        public java.util.List<Frame> path(Frame tail,
                                  Frame tip)
        Returns a straight path of frames between tail and tip. Returns an empty list if either tail or tip aren't reachable. Use Frame.path(Frame, Frame) to include all frames even if they aren't reachable.

        If tail is ancestor of tip the returned list will include both of them. Otherwise it will be empty.

        See Also:
        isReachable(Frame), Frame.path(Frame, Frame)

      • computeProjection

        public Matrix computeProjection()
        Computes and returns the projection matrix associated with the graph.

        If the graph type is PERSPECTIVE, defines a projection matrix using the fieldOfView(), aspectRatio(), zNear() and zFar() parameters.

        If the graph type is ORTHOGRAPHIC or TWO_D, the frustum's width and height are set using boundaryWidthHeight().

        Both PERSPECTIVE and ORTHOGRAPHIC types use zNear() and zFar() to place the clipping planes. These values are determined from radius() and center() so that they best fit the graph size.

        Override computeCustomProjection() to define a CUSTOM projection. Note 1: This method is called by preDraw(). Note 2: Note that the computation of both, the PERSPECTIVE and ORTHOGRAPHIC frustum shapes depend on the eye magnitude, see fieldOfView() and boundaryWidthHeight().

        public void setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler matrixHandler)
        Sets the MatrixHandler defining how dandelion matrices are to be handled.

      • isPointVisible

        public boolean isPointVisible(Vector point)
        Returns true if point is visible (i.e, lies within the eye boundary) and false otherwise. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations()) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).
        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • ballVisibility

        public Graph.Visibility ballVisibility(Vector center,
                                       float radius)
        Returns Graph.Visibility.VISIBLE, Graph.Visibility.INVISIBLE, or Graph.Visibility.SEMIVISIBLE, depending whether the sphere (of radius radius and center center) is visible, invisible, or semi-visible, respectively. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations() ) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).
        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), isPointVisible(Vector), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • boxVisibility

        public Graph.Visibility boxVisibility(Vector corner1,
                                      Vector corner2)
        Returns Graph.Visibility.VISIBLE, Graph.Visibility.INVISIBLE, or Graph.Visibility.SEMIVISIBLE, depending whether the axis aligned box (defined by corners p1 and p2) is visible, invisible, or semi-visible, respectively. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations() ) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).
        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • updateBoundaryEquations

        public float[][] updateBoundaryEquations()
        Returns the 4 or 6 plane equations of the eye boundary.

        In 2D the four 4-component vectors, respectively correspond to the left, right, top and bottom eye boundary lines. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c = 0 where a, b and c are the 3 components of each vector, in that order.

        In 3D the six 4-component vectors, respectively correspond to the left, right, near, far, top and bottom frustum planes. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0

        where a, b, c and d are the 4 components of each vector, in that order. Attention: You should not call this method explicitly, unless you need the frustum equations to be updated only occasionally (rare). Use enableBoundaryEquations() which automatically update the frustum equations every frame instead.

      • disableBoundaryEquations

        public void disableBoundaryEquations()
        Disables automatic update of the frustum plane equations every frame. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        areBoundaryEquationsEnabled(), enableBoundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations(boolean), updateBoundaryEquations()

      • enableBoundaryEquations

        public void enableBoundaryEquations()
        Enables automatic update of the frustum plane equations every frame. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        areBoundaryEquationsEnabled(), disableBoundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations(boolean), updateBoundaryEquations()

      • enableBoundaryEquations

        public void enableBoundaryEquations(boolean flag)
        Enables or disables automatic update of the eye boundary plane equations every frame according to flag. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        updateBoundaryEquations()

      • areBoundaryEquationsEnabled

        public boolean areBoundaryEquationsEnabled()
        Returns true if automatic update of the eye boundary plane equations is enabled and false otherwise. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        updateBoundaryEquations()

      • boundaryEquations

        public float[][] boundaryEquations()
        Returns the boundary plane equations.

        In 2D the four 4-component vectors, respectively correspond to the left, right, top and bottom eye boundary lines. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c = 0 where a, b and c are the 3 components of each vector, in that order.

        In 3D the six 4-component vectors returned by this method, respectively correspond to the left, right, near, far, top and bottom eye boundary planes. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0

        where a, b, c and d are the 4 components of each vector, in that order. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations()) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).

        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • distanceToBoundary

        public float distanceToBoundary(int index,
                                Vector position)
        Returns the signed distance between point position and plane index in world units. The distance is negative if the point lies in the planes's boundary halfspace, and positive otherwise.

        In 2D index is a value between 0 and 3 which respectively correspond to the left, right, top and bottom eye boundary planes.

        In 3D index is a value between 0 and 5 which respectively correspond to the left, right, near, far, top and bottom eye boundary planes. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations()) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).

        See Also:
        isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • pixelToGraphRatio

        public float pixelToGraphRatio(Vector position)
        Returns the pixel to graph (units) ratio at position.

        Convenience function that simply returns 1 / graphToPixelRatio(position).

        See Also:
        graphToPixelRatio(Vector)

      • graphToPixelRatio

        public float graphToPixelRatio(Vector position)
        Returns the ratio of graph (units) to pixel at position.

        A line of n * graphToPixelRatio() graph units, located at position in the world coordinates system, will be projected with a length of n pixels on screen.

        Use this method to scale objects so that they have a constant pixel size on screen. The following code will draw a 20 pixel line, starting at center() and always directed along the screen vertical direction:

        beginShape(LINES);
        vertex(sceneCenter().x, sceneCenter().y, sceneCenter().z);
        Vector v = Vector.add(sceneCenter(), Vector.mult(upVector(), 20 * graphToPixelRatio(sceneCenter())));
        vertex(v.x, v.y, v.z);
        endShape();

      • radius

        public float radius()
        Returns the radius of the graph observed by the eye in world units.

        In 3D you need to provide such an approximation of the graph dimensions so that the it can adapt its zNear() and zFar() values. See the center() documentation.

        Note that radius() (resp. setRadius(float) simply call this method on its associated eye.

        See Also:
        setBoundingBox(Vector, Vector)

      • center

        public Vector center()
        Returns the position of the graph center, defined in the world coordinate system.

        The graph observed by the eye should be roughly centered on this position, and included in a radius() ball.

        Default value is the world origin. Use setCenter(Vector) to change it.

        See Also:
        setCenter(Vector), setRadius(float), setBoundingBox(Vector, Vector), zNear(), zFar()

      • anchor

        public Vector anchor()
        The point the eye revolves around with a ROTATE gesture. Defined in world coordinate system.

        Default value is the center(). Use setAnchor(Vector) to change it.

        See Also:
        setAnchor(Vector)

      • setAnchor

        public void setAnchor(Vector anchor)
        Sets the anchor(), defined in the world coordinate system.

        Sets the radius() value in world units.

      • setBoundingBox

        public void setBoundingBox(Vector corner1,
                           Vector corner2)
        Similar to setRadius(float) and setCenter(Vector), but the graph limits are defined by a world axis aligned bounding box.

      • viewDirection

        public Vector viewDirection()
        Returns the normalized view direction of the eye, defined in the world coordinate system. This corresponds to the negative Z axis of the eye() (frame().worldDisplacement(new Vector(0.0f, 0.0f, -1.0f))). In 2D it always is (0,0,-1).

        Change this value using setViewDirection(Vector), lookAt(Vector) or Frame.setOrientation(Quaternion). It is orthogonal to upVector() and to rightVector().

      • setViewDirection

        public void setViewDirection(Vector direction)
        Rotates the eye so that its viewDirection() is direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

        The eye Frame.position() is not modified. The eye is rotated so that the horizon (defined by its upVector()) is preserved.

        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector), setUpVector(Vector)

      • setUpVector

        public void setUpVector(Vector up)
        Convenience function that simply calls setUpVector(up, true).
        See Also:
        setUpVector(Vector, boolean)

      • setUpVector

        public void setUpVector(Vector up,
                        boolean noMove)
        Rotates the eye so that its upVector() becomes up (defined in the world coordinate system).

        The eye is rotated around an axis orthogonal to up and to the current upVector() direction.

        Use this method in order to define the eye horizontal plane.

        When noMove is set to false, the orientation modification is compensated by a translation, so that the anchor() stays projected at the same position on screen. This is especially useful when the eye is an observer of the graph (default action binding).

        When noMove is true, the Eye Frame.position() is left unchanged, which is an intuitive behavior when the Eye is in first person mode.

        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector)

      • upVector

        public Vector upVector()
        Returns the normalized up vector of the eye, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Set using setUpVector(Vector) or Frame.setOrientation(Quaternion). It is orthogonal to viewDirection() and to rightVector().

        It corresponds to the Y axis of the associated eye() (actually returns frame().yAxis()

      • lookAt

        public void lookAt(Vector target)
        2D eyes simply call frame().setPosition(target.x(), target.y()). 3D eyes set Frame.orientation(), so that it looks at point target defined in the world coordinate system (The eye Frame.position() is not modified. Simply setViewDirection(Vector)).
        See Also:
        at(), setUpVector(Vector), fitBall(), fitBall(Vector, float), fitBoundingBox(Vector, Vector)

      • rightVector

        public Vector rightVector()
        Returns the normalized right vector of the eye, defined in the world coordinate system.

        This vector lies in the eye horizontal plane, directed along the X axis (orthogonal to upVector() and to viewDirection(). Set using setUpVector(Vector), lookAt(Vector) or Frame.setOrientation(Quaternion).

        Simply returns frame().xAxis().

      • at

        public Vector at()
        2D eyes return the position. 3D eyes return a point defined in the world coordinate system where the eyes is pointing at (just in front of viewDirection()). Useful for setting the Processing camera() which uses a similar approach of that found in gluLookAt.
        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector)

      • interpolator

        public Interpolator interpolator()
        Returns the eye() Interpolator used by fitBallInterpolation(), zoomOnRegionInterpolation(Rectangle), interpolateTo(Frame), etc.

      • interpolateTo

        public void interpolateTo(Frame frame)
        Convenience function that simply calls interpolateTo(fr, 1).
        See Also:
        interpolateTo(Frame, float)

      • interpolateTo

        public void interpolateTo(Frame frame,
                          float duration)
        Smoothly interpolates the eye on a interpolator path so that it goes to frame.

        frame is expressed in world coordinates. duration tunes the interpolation speed.

        See Also:
        interpolateTo(Frame), fitBallInterpolation()

      • zoomOnRegionInterpolation

        public void zoomOnRegionInterpolation(Rectangle rectangle)
        Smoothly moves the eye so that the rectangular screen region defined by rectangle (pixel units, with origin in the upper left corner) fits the screen.

        The eye is translated (its Frame.orientation() is unchanged) so that rectangle is entirely visible. Since the pixel coordinates only define a boundary in 3D, it's the intersection of this boundary with a plane (orthogonal to the viewDirection() and passing through the center()) that is used to define the 3D rectangle that is eventually fitted.

      • fitBallInterpolation

        public void fitBallInterpolation()
        Interpolates the eye so that the entire graph fits the screen.

        The graph is defined by its center() and its radius(). See fitBall().

        The Frame.orientation() of the eye() is not modified.

      • fitBall

        public void fitBall()
        Same as fitBall(center(), radius()).
        See Also:
        fitBall(Vector, float), center(), radius()

      • fitBall

        public void fitBall(Vector center,
                    float radius)
        Moves the eye so that the ball defined by center and radius is visible and fits the window.

        In 3D the eye is simply translated along its viewDirection() so that the sphere fits the screen. Its Frame.orientation() and its fieldOfView() are unchanged. You should therefore orientate the eye before you call this method.

        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector), setUpVector(Vector, boolean)

      • fitBoundingBox

        public void fitBoundingBox(Vector corner1,
                           Vector corner2)
        Moves the eye so that the world axis aligned bounding box (corner1 and corner2) is entirely visible, using fitBall(Vector, float).

      • zoomOnRegion

        public void zoomOnRegion(Rectangle rectangle)
        Moves the eye so that the rectangular screen region defined by rectangle (pixel units, with origin in the upper left corner) fits the screen.

        in 3D the eye is translated (its Frame.orientation() is unchanged) so that rectangle is entirely visible. Since the pixel coordinates only define a frustum in 3D, it's the intersection of this frustum with a plane (orthogonal to the viewDirection() and passing through the center()) that is used to define the 3D rectangle that is eventually fitted.

      • convertClickToLine

        public void convertClickToLine(Point pixel,
                               Vector origin,
                               Vector direction)
        Gives the coefficients of a 3D half-line passing through the eye and pixel (x,y). Origin in the upper left corner. Use height() - y to locate the origin at the lower left corner.

        The origin of the half line (eye position) is stored in orig, while dir contains the properly oriented and normalized direction of the half line.

        This method is useful for analytical intersection in a selection method.

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(Frame frame)
        Apply the local transformation defined by frame, i.e., respect to its Frame.reference(). The Frame is first translated, then rotated around the new translated origin and then scaled.

        This method may be used to modify the modelview matrix from a frame hierarchy. For example, with this frame hierarchy:

        Frame body = new Frame();
        Frame leftArm = new Frame();
        Frame rightArm = new Frame();
        leftArm.setReference(body);
        rightArm.setReference(body);

        The associated drawing code should look like:

        pushModelView();
        applyTransformation(body);
        drawBody();
        pushModelView();
        applyTransformation(leftArm);
        drawArm();
        popMatrix();
        pushMatrix();
        applyTransformation(rightArm);
        drawArm();
        popModelView();
        popModelView();

        Note the use of nested pushModelView() and popModelView() blocks to represent the frame hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        See Also:
        applyWorldTransformation(Frame)

      • applyWorldTransformation

        public void applyWorldTransformation(Frame frame)
        Same as applyTransformation(Frame), but applies the global transformation defined by the frame.

      • track

        public Frame track(java.lang.String hid,
                   float x,
                   float y,
                   Frame[] frameArray)
        Updates the hid device tracked-frame from the frameArray and returns it.

        To set the trackedFrame(String) the algorithm casts a ray at pixel position (x, y) (see tracks(float, float, Frame)). If no frame is found under the pixel, it returns null.

        Use this version of the method instead of track(String, float, float) when dealing with detached frames.

        See Also:

      • track

        public Frame track(java.lang.String hid,
                   float x,
                   float y)
        Updates the hid device tracked-frame and returns it.

        To set the trackedFrame(String) the algorithm casts a ray at pixel position (x, y) (see tracks(float, float, Frame)). If no frame is found under the pixel, it returns null.

        Use this version of the method instead of track(String, float, float, Frame[]) when dealing with attached frames to the graph.

        track(String, float, float, Frame[]), traverse(), trackedFrame(String), resetTrackedFrame(String), defaultFrame(String), tracks(float, float, Frame), setTrackedFrame(String, Frame), isTrackedFrame(String, Frame), Frame.enableTracking(boolean), Frame.precision(), Frame.setPrecision(Frame.Precision), cast(String, Point), cast(String, float, float)

      • cast

        public void cast(java.lang.String hid,
                 Point pixel)
        Same as track(String, Point) but doesn't return immediately the hid device tracked-frame. The algorithm schedules an updated of the hid tracked-frame for the next traversal and hence should be always be used in conjunction with traverse().

        This method is optimal since it updated the hid tracked-frame at traversal time. Prefer this method over track(String, Point) when dealing with several hids.

        See Also:
        traverse(), trackedFrame(String), resetTrackedFrame(String), defaultFrame(String), tracks(float, float, Frame), setTrackedFrame(String, Frame), isTrackedFrame(String, Frame), Frame.enableTracking(boolean), Frame.precision(), Frame.setPrecision(Frame.Precision), cast(String, float, float)

      • traverse

        public void traverse()
        Traverse the frame hierarchy, successively applying the local transformation defined by each traversed frame, and calling Frame.visit() on it.

        Note that only reachable frames are visited by this algorithm. Attention: this method should be called within the main event loop, just after preDraw() (i.e., eye update) and before any other transformation of the modelview matrix takes place.

        See Also:
        track(String, float, float), isReachable(Frame), pruneBranch(Frame)

      • screenLocation

        Convenience function that simply returns screenLocation(src, null).
        See Also:

      • screenLocation

        public Vector screenLocation(Vector vector,
                             Frame frame)
        Converts vector location from frame to screen. Use location(vector, frame) to perform the inverse transformation.

        The x and y coordinates of the returned vector are expressed in screen coordinates, (0,0) being the upper left corner of the window. The z coordinate ranges between 0 (near plane) and 1 (excluded, far plane).

        See Also:
        screenLocation(Vector), location(Vector, Frame), location(Vector)

      • location

        public Vector location(Vector pixel)
        Convenience function that simply returns location(pixel, null).

        #see location(Vector, Frame)

      • location

        public Vector location(Vector pixel,
                       Frame frame)
        Returns the frame coordinates of pixel.

        The pixel (0,0) corresponds to the upper left corner of the window. The pixel.z() is a depth value ranging in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D note that pixel.z is not a linear interpolation between zNear() and zFar(); pixel.z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z); where z is the distance from the point you project to the camera, along the viewDirection().

        The result is expressed in the frame coordinate system. When frame is null, the result is expressed in the world coordinates system. The possible frame hierarchy (i.e., when Frame.reference() is non-null) is taken into account.

        screenLocation(Vector, Frame) performs the inverse transformation.

        This method only uses the intrinsic eye parameters (view and projection matrices), width() and height()). You can hence define a virtual eye and use this method to compute un-projections out of a classical rendering context.

        This method is not computationally optimized by default. If you call it several times with no change in the matrices, you should buffer the inverse of the projection times view matrix to speed-up the queries. See cacheProjectionViewInverse(boolean).

        See Also:
        screenLocation(Vector, Frame), setWidth(int), setHeight(int)

        See Also:

      • rotate

        public void rotate(float roll,
                   float pitch,
                   float yaw,
                   Frame frame)
        Rotates the frame roll, pitch and yaw radians relative to the screen space x, y and z axes, respectively. The center of the rotation is the graph anchor() if the frame is the eye(), or the frame origin (see Frame.position()) otherwise.

        To rotate an eye frame around its origin and local axes simply call: eye().rotate(new Quaternion(roll, pitch, yaw)).

        See Also:
        rotate(String, float, float, float), spin(Point, Point, float, Frame)

      • spin

        public void spin(Point tail,
                 Point head,
                 float sensitivity,
                 Frame frame)
        Rotates the frame using an arcball interface, from tail to head pixel positions. The sensitivity controls the gesture strength. The center of the rotation is the graph anchor() if the frame is the eye(), or the frame origin (see Frame.position()) otherwise.

        For implementation details refer to Shoemake 92 paper: Arcball: a user interface for specifying three-dimensional orientation using a mouse.

        Override this class an call _spin(Point, Point, Point, float, Frame) if you want to define a different rotation center (rare).

        See Also:
        spin(String, Point, Point), spin(Point, Point, Frame), spin(String, Point, Point, float), rotate(float, float, float, Frame)

      • spin

        public void spin(Quaternion quaternion,
                 Frame frame)
        Rotates the frame using quaternion around its Frame.position() (non-eye frames) or around the anchor() when the frame is the eye().

      • lookAround

                       float deltaY)
        Look around (without translating the eye) according to angular displacements deltaX and deltaY expressed in radians.

      • rotateCAD

        public void rotateCAD(float roll,
                      float pitch)
        Same as rotateCAD(roll, pitch, new Vector(0, 1, 0)).
        See Also:
        rotateCAD(float, float, Vector)

      • rotateCAD

        public void rotateCAD(float roll,
                      float pitch,
                      Vector upVector)
        Defines an axis which the eye rotates around. The eye can rotate left or right around this axis. It can also be moved up or down to show the 'top' and 'bottom' views of the scene. As a result, the upVector will always appear vertical in the scene, and the horizon is preserved and stays projected along the eye's horizontal axis.

        This method requires calling scene.eye().setYAxis(upVector) (see Frame.setYAxis(Vector)) and fitBall() first.

        See Also:
        rotateCAD(float, float)

      • defaultHIDControl

        public void defaultHIDControl(java.lang.Object... gesture)
        Same as control(defaultFrame(), gesture). This method implements application control with the defaultFrame() which requires overriding Frame.interact(Object...).
        See Also:
        defaultFrame(), control(Frame, Object...)

      • control

        public void control(java.lang.String hid,
                    java.lang.Object... gesture)
        Same as control(defaultFrame(hid), gesture). This method implements application control with the defaultFrame(String) which requires overriding Frame.interact(Object...).
        See Also:
        defaultFrame(String), control(Frame, Object...)

      • control

        public void control(Frame frame,
                    java.lang.Object... gesture)
        Same as frame.interact(gesture).
        See Also:
        defaultHIDControl(Object...), control(String, Object...), Frame.interact(Object...)
